title: How to Bake Hurry Up Yellow Cake with Plums

steps.headline: Stir the cake flour and sugar together in a large bowl.
Add in all the remaining ingredients except for the plums.
steps.description: Using a wire whisk, beat these ingredients rather energetically for 2-3 minutes. If you want only part of the cake with nuts, don't add the nuts in until specified in Step 4.

steps.headline: Halve and de-pit the plums.
steps.description: You'll need enough to cover the bottom of the cake pan with; if you're using small plums that might mean around 40 plums. In the pictures greengage plums were used, but you can use any type so long as they're ripe.

steps.headline: Lay the plums face-down in the 9x13" cake pan and pour the batter over them.
steps.description:
If you decided to only use walnuts in half the cake, add the nuts to the batter after pouring half of it into the pan. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg\/460px-Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg\/760px-Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Bake the cake at 350F for 30 minutes.
steps.description: The cake should be a light golden shade when done.

steps.headline: Ice the cake if you have an inclination for such, and serve with vanilla ice cream.
steps.description: Both cocoa butter and lemon icing are tasty options; the cake pictured here is iced with lemon icing. Store any leftovers in the fridge; with icing this cake keeps good for several days.

text:
Stir the cake flour and sugar together in a large bowl. Add in all the remaining ingredients except for the plums. Using a wire whisk, beat these ingredients rather energetically for 2-3 minutes. If you want only part of the cake with nuts, don't add the nuts in until specified in Step 4. Halve and de-pit the plums. You'll need enough to cover the bottom of the cake pan with; if you're using small plums that might mean around 40 plums. In the pictures greengage plums were used, but you can use any type so long as they're ripe. Lay the plums face-down in the 9x13" cake pan and pour the batter over them. If you decided to only use walnuts in half the cake, add the nuts to the batter after pouring half of it into the pan. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg\/460px-Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/63\/Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg\/760px-Ready-to-go-in-oven.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the cake at 350F for 30 minutes. The cake should be a light golden shade when done. Ice the cake if you have an inclination for such, and serve with vanilla ice cream. Both cocoa butter and lemon icing are tasty options; the cake pictured here is iced with lemon icing. Store any leftovers in the fridge; with icing this cake keeps good for several days.
